author: Mike Cetera
title: How the App Store breach affects users
text:
Finance Blogs » Mobile Finance Blog » How the App Store breach affects users How the App Store breach affects users Email 
Potentially hundreds of millions of Apple users could be impacted by malware found in dozens of apps that were available for download in the App Store, according to research from security firm Palo Alto Networks. 
Chinese iOS developers disclosed the malware, named XcodeGhost, last week after hackers persuaded developers of legitimate apps to use a counterfeit version of software used to create mobile and desktop apps. The hackers planted malicious code on that fake software. Phishing attacks detected 
This marks the first major successful attack on Apple's mobile software site. Apple has since removed the affected apps, but not before the malware had "already launched phishing attacks to prompt a dialog asking victims to input their iCloud passwords," Palo Alto noted in a blog post. 
The malware also could, according to Palo Alto, read a user's password if that password was copied from a password management tool onto the user's clipboard. More to come? 
In an interview with Reuters, a Palo Alto representative said his firm had not found any instances of data theft as a result of this hack. However, in its blog post, the company called XcodeGhost "very harmful and dangerous," in part because it shows how iOS can be infiltrated. 
"The techniques used in this attack could be adopted by criminal and espionage focused groups to gain access to iOS devices," according to the blog post. Affected apps 
The 39 infected apps identified by Palo Alto include instant messaging, banking and stock-trading apps. The firm said the well-known apps affected include WeChat and Didi Chuxing, an Uber challenger in China. 
"Apple takes security very seriously and iOS is designed to be reliable and secure from the moment you turn on your device," Apple said in a statement.
